title: I’m 32, is it too late to become a professional musician? - Quora

response.answer_text: Probably. The thing about becoming a professional musician is it takes years and years and years of working away getting no money at all. Literally nothing. You have to get really good, then have a lucky break. Most professional musicians aren’t that brilliant at their instruments they were just in the right place at the right time. Now there’s a lot of skill involved with putting yourself in the right place at the right time, but there’s still a huge amount of luck as well. You just have to plug away on some music scene somewhere, get well known to everyone on the scene as being good, then hope someone who notices you is in a position where they can pay you. It takes a very long time. Most people are going to quit before they have their lucky break. The thing is, if you start doing it at 16, it might take you 10 years before anything happens. That means you’ll be 26 before you start making a proper living from it. Until then you’ll be working in bars or whatever to make ends meet, and fit it all around your music. It’s ok to still be doing that at 26. But if you start at 32 and it takes you until you are 42 to get the break, do you still want to be working in bars and living off tips when you are 42? Really I think you need to give it at least 10 years before you can really say you’ve given it a go. And furthermore, most people will not “make it” as a professional musician. You might make a bit of money here and there but not enough to live off. It’s a big gamble to take at 32. Trying to find a new career at 42 when it hasn’t worked out sounds like hard work to me. Id rather do something else and keep music as a hobby if I were you.

Time for some brutal honesty: This question is like asking: “I’m 32… is it too late to spend the rest of my life doing what makes me really happy? Or should I just spend the rest of my life in misery because I ‘happen’ to have been born 32 years ago?” The answer’s pretty obvious when you put the question like this, doesn’t it? In all seriousness: You do only really have a short time to live, regardless of how old you happen to be right now. Does the “quantity” of time you’ve lived (or have left to live) really matter most to you? Or is it the quality?
